[[United States]] | death_date = | death_place = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Singing|vocals]] | genre = [[Blues rock]], [[blues]], [[rock music|rock]], [[roots rock]], [[hard rock]] | occupation = [[Musician]], [[Songwriter]] | years_active = 1990-present | label = [[Roadrunner Records]] | associated_acts = Kenny Wayne Shepherd Band
[[G3 (tour)|G3]]
[[The Rides]] | website = [http://www.kennywayneshepherd.net/ Official Website] | notable_instruments = [[Fender Stratocaster|Kenny Wayne Shepherd Signature Series Stratocaster]] }} '''Kenny Wayne Shepherd''' (born '''Kenny Wayne Brobst'''; June 12, 1977) is an [[United States|American]] [[guitarist]], [[singer]], and [[songwriter]]. He has released several [[studio album]]s and experienced significant commercial success both as a blues artist and a young musician.[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p21347|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic - biography page] ==Life and career== [[File:Stephen Stills and Kenny Wayne Shepherd 9-7-2013.jpg|thumb|240px|[[Stephen Stills]] and Shepherd (front) and Barry Goldberg, not visible, performing as The Rides in Boston, Sept. 7, 2013.]] Shepherd was born in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], [[Louisiana]].[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1351849/bio IMDb - Kenny Wayne Shepherd Biography] Accessed January 2008 He graduated [[Caddo Magnet High School]] in Shreveport. The guitarist is "completely self taught", {{cite news | first= Nic | last= Harcourt | title= Kenny Wayne Shepherd: Guitar Center Sessions (interview with [[Nic Harcourt]]) | date= air date February 12, 2011 | publisher= DirecTV}} and does not read music. Growing up, Shepherd's father (Ken Shepherd) was a local radio personality and some-time concert promoter, and had a vast collection of music. Shepherd got his first "guitar" at the age of three or four, when his grandmother purchased a series of several plastic guitars for him with [[S&H Green Stamps]], which Shepherd has said he would "go through like candy".Harcourt Guitar Center interview, air date 02/12/2011{{Clarify|reason=ambiguous date format|date=February 2011}} Shepherd stated in a 2010 interview that he began playing guitar in earnest at age seven, about six months after meeting and being "pretty mesmerized" by [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]], in June 1984, at one of his father's promoted concerts. His self-taught method employed a process of learning one note at a time, playing and rewinding cassette tapes, using "a cheap Yamaha wanna-be Stratocaster...made out of plywood, basically", and learning to play by following along with material from his father's record collection. At the age of 13, Shepherd was invited to play guitar onstage by blues musician [[Bryan Lee]]. He subsequently made demo tapes, and a video was shot at Shepherd's first performance at the [[Red River Revel]] Arts Festival in Shreveport. It was this video performance that impressed [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]] chief [[Irving Azoff]] enough to sign Shepherd to a multiple album record deal. From 1995 on, Shepherd took seven [[single (music)|single]]s into the Top 10, and holds the record for the longest-running album on the ''Billboard'' Blues Charts with ''[[Trouble Is...]]''. In 1996, Shepherd began a longtime collaboration with vocalist [[Noah Hunt]], who provided the vocals for Shepherd's signature song, "[[Blue on Black]]". Shepherd has been nominated for five [[Grammy Award]]s, and has received two [[Billboard Music Award]]s, two [[Blues Music Award]]s and two Orville H. Gibson Awards. In September 2008, Fender Musical Instruments Corp. released the Kenny Wayne Shepherd Signature Series Stratocaster, designed exclusively by Shepherd. In 2007, he released a critically acclaimed and two time [[Grammy]] nominated DVD–CD project, ''[[10 Days Out: Blues from the Backroads]]''. This documents Shepherd as he travels the country to [[jam session|jam]] with and interview the last of the authentic blues musicians. As they tour the backroads, Shepherd, with members of the Double Trouble Band, play with a host of blues greats including [[Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown]] and Bryan Lee, Buddy Flett (with whom he jams at [[Lead Belly]]'s grave), [[B. B. King]], blues harp master [[Jerry McCain|Jerry "Boogie" McCain]], [[Cootie Stark]], [[Neal Pattman]], [[John Dee Holeman]], [[Etta Baker]], [[Henry Townsend (musician)|Henry Townsend]] with [[Honeyboy Edwards]], and a concert session with the surviving members of Muddy Waters' and [[Howlin' Wolf]]'s bands, including luminaries such as [[Hubert Sumlin]], [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]] and [[Pinetop Perkins]]. In 2010 Shepherd was nominated for a Grammy for ''Live In Chicago'' which featured performances with Hubert Sumlin, Willie "Big Eyes" Smith, Buddy Flett and Bryan Lee. In 2011, Shepherd released his seventh CD entitled ''How I Go'' on Roadrunner Records. ===Personal life=== Shepherd married actor [[Mel Gibson]]'s eldest daughter, Hannah, on September 16, 2006,{{cite web|url=http://www.tmz.com/2006/09/18/mel-walks-his-daughter-down-the-aisle/ |title=Mel Walks His Daughter Down the Aisle |publisher=TMZ.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-31}} and they have three children, a daughter born October 10, 2007, and sons born 2009 and March 12, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/momsbabies/news/mel-gibson-welcomes-third-grandchild-2011143 |title=Mel Gibson Welcomes Third Grandchild |publisher=UsMagazine.com |date=2011-03-14 |accessdate=2011-12-31}} ==Live performances== * Shepherd made a trip of ten days in the [[United States|U.S.]] to meet and play with his idols: [[B.B. King]], [[Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown]], [[Hubert Sumlin]], [[Pinetop Perkins]], [[Henry Townsend (musician)|Henry Townsend]], [[David Honeyboy Edwards|Honeyboy Edwards]], [[Cootie Stark]], [[Neal Pattman]], [[Etta Baker]], [[Jerry McCain|Jerry "Boogie" McCain]], [[Buddy Flett]], [[Bryan Lee]], [[John Dee Holeman]], The [[Howlin' Wolf]] and the [[Muddy Waters]] Band. * Shepherd and Bryan Lee appeared as the musical guest on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' with [[Jay Leno]] on February 14, 2007. *On July 24, 2007, he opened for [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] at the [[Orange County Fair]]{{dn|date=November 2013}}. *He was the opening act for [[The Rolling Stones]] during a stint of their [[1999 in music|1999]] [[No Security]] tour. *Shepherd performed some of his songs including a cover of [[Jimi Hendrix]]'s "[[Voodoo Child (Slight Return)|Voodoo Child]]" at the Dutch Mason Blues Festival in 2007 and 2009. *Has also opened for [[Aerosmith]], [[Bob Dylan]], the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] (originally on the [[Hell Freezes Over]] Tour), and [[Van Halen]]. *''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' performance, Nov 2010 - Shepherd sat in with house band, playing the same white [[Stratocaster]] played by [[Jimi Hendrix]] during his historic performance at [[Woodstock]]. *On January 15, 2011, Shepherd performed a live set for "[[Guitar Center]] Sessions" on [[DirecTV]]. The episode included an interview with Shepherd by program host, [[Nic Harcourt]].[http://sessions.guitarcenter.com/kenny-wayne-shepherd Guitar Center Sessions with host Nic Harcourt] Retrieved July 15, 2013. * Shepherd appeared at the Experience Hendrix tribute concert in Mesa Arizona on May 23, 2011. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Album details ! colspan="6"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:130px;"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] |- ! style="width:3em;font-size:75%;"| [[Billboard 200|US]]
